answers.author: Christopher Anderson
answers.text:
Regarding your questions about frank conversations on the internet:  I don't think managers are reluctant to speak openly with each other.  I think having all our communications available for public scrutiny is the obstacle, and even the anonymity you suggest would not resolve that issue.  I liked your survey!

author: Joshua Rauch
text:
Hi all,
I've spent the past few weeks contemplating how we all use the internet as public administrators. This started out as a small survey, but I'm trying to broaden the pool of respondents. If you have a few moments and don't mind sharing your anonymous opinion, click here to take the survey (it's about 10 questions; most are yes/no): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dEh5a2xLTzl1a255Q09fM0lhVWNTM1E6MQ#gid=0
I've written a (relatively) short blog entry about my results so far here: http://www.joshrauch.com/2012/07/31/the-internet-you/
If you're interested in the context, that blog entry should help.
This is primarily a personal project, as I'm trying to understand how people in our profession understand their professional interactions online. The survey is obviously unscientific and informal.
Thanks for your time and feedback.
Sincerely,
Josh Rauch
title: The Internet and You
